snippet: Regulators released contingency plans for nine large banks in the event of a collapse, but skeptics say that failures unfold unpredictably.
abstract: Federal regulators release so-called living wills for nine of the nation's largest banks; move puts in place contingency plans in the event of a collapse, but skeptics say financial failures are unpredictable and that banks are still too big to fail without sending shock waves through the financial system.

byline.original: By JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG and NELSON D. SCHWARTZ

lead_paragraph: Regulators released contingency plans for nine large banks in the event of a collapse, but skeptics say that failures unfold unpredictably.

headline.seo: ‘Living Wills’ of How to Unwind Big Banks Are Released
headline.main: ‘Living Wills’ for Too-Big-to-Fail Banks Are Released
headline.print_headline: Federal Regulators Make Public the ‘Living Wills’ of Nine Too-Big-to-Fail Banks

keywords.value: Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject
